Award.AwardTitle: Travel Support: 19th US-Japan Conference on Composite Materials and Visit to Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA); Kakuda Space Center, Sendai, Japan; July 21-24, 2020

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides travel support for the 19th US-Japan Conference on Composite Materials (CCM) from July 22-24, 2020 and visit to the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA) Kakuda Space Center, on July 21, 2020, in Sendai, Japan. The 19th US-Japan CCM is the next in a series of conferences organized by the Japan Society for Composite Materials and the American Society for Composites to promote science of composite materials and provide a platform for the intellectual exchange between US and Japanese researchers. Composite materials research enabled development of ground-breaking technologies across a wide spectrum of industries such as aerospace, clean energy, and automotive, that are vital to the United States’ economy, national security, and the nation's current standing as the world’s leading research- and technology-driven society. Early-career faculty from US universities will be the primary recipients of the travel support. A special emphasis will be placed on engagement of faculty from underrepresented groups and minority-serving institutions.

The main theme of the 19th US-Japan CCM is mechanics of composite materials. For the first time, the US-Japan CCM will be collocated with the Euro-Japan Conference on Composite Materials, which is supported by the European Society for Composite Materials and Japan Society for Composite Materials. The award will provide a rare opportunity for the early career faculty from the US institutions of higher education to participate in the US-Japan and Euro-Japan CCM, visit the JAXA Kakuda Space Center and get a deeper perspective on the ongoing research and development in composite materials in Japan. Carefully devised group activities will promote intellectual exchange, development of international research and mentorship networks, and support professional success of the early career faculty from diverse backgrounds and institutions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The award bolstered international collaboration as well as facilitated mentorship by providing travel support to a group of thirteen US researchers to attend and present at the US-Japan Joint Symposium for Composite Materials in Tokyo, Japan, and to visit the Structures and Advanced Composite Research Unit of Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA) in Tokyo, Japan. With this award, the PIs specifically targeted early career faculty from US universities, in particular faculty from underrepresented groups and minority-serving institutions.

 

Intellectual Merit: The award provided a unique opportunity for the U.S. participants to

-        Engage in first-hand interactions with Japanese researchers;

-        Strengthen US-Japan intellectual exchange and initiate new research collaborations in the area of composite materials;

-        Advance scientific knowledge in mechanics of composites through exploring different research perspectives and approaches.

 

Broader Impact:

Composite materials and associated technologies play a central role in aerospace, automotive, maritime, etc., industries. Specific examples: in transportation, composite structure technology have enabled the improved fuel efficiency via weight reduction; composites are critical in the creation of larger wind energy systems. Active international communication and collaboration are vital for preserving our nations’ leading position in research and technological innovation. The award provided an exceptional opportunity for the faculty from the US institutions of higher education to participate in the US-Japan Joint Symposium for Composite Materials in Tokyo, Japan and to visit JAXA, and obtain a first-hand exposure to the most recent advances in research and development in composite materials in Japan. The PIs actively promoted diversity by ensuring participation of faculty from underrepresented groups (46%) and minority-serving institutions (46%). Group activities facilitated mentorship, professional development, and building professional networks among a diverse group of the US and Japanese researchers.

Modified by: Olesya Zhupanska
